turkey.factoid: A fun fact about turkey is that the average turkey can run up to 20 miles per hour!

vicu\u00f1a.factoid: Vicuñas are the smallest member of the camelid family and are found in the Andean highlands of Peru, Bolivia, Ecuador, and Argentina. vulture.factoid: Vultures have an incredible sense of smell and can detect the scent of carrion (dead animals) from up to 1.8 miles away!

wallaby.factoid: Wallabies can jump up to 3 meters high and can reach speeds of 50 km/hour when leaping.

walrus.factoid: Walruses have the longest tusks of any living mammal. The tusks can grow up to three feet long and are used for fighting, defense, and foraging for food.

wasp.factoid: Wasps are a vital part of the ecosystem, as they help control insect populations by preying on them. Wasps can also be beneficial pollinators, as they are important for fertilizing flowers while they search for nectar.

water-buffalo.factoid: Water-buffalo are the largest members of the bovine family and can weigh up to 2,200 pounds!

weasel.factoid: Weasels are one of the few animals that can turn their heads almost 180 degrees!

whale.factoid: harksWhale sharks are the largest fish species in the world and can grow up to 12 metres (40 feet) in length. They are filter feeders, meaning they eat plankton, krill, and small fish.

wolf.factoid: piders?Wolf spiders are capable of running up to 1.5 meters per second, making them some of the fastest spiders in the world!

wolverine.factoid: Wolverines have been known to take down prey much larger than themselves, including moose, elk, and even bears.

wombat.factoid: oop?Wombat poop is cube-shaped! This is due to the wombat's unique digestive system, which allows them to absorb more nutrients from their food.

woodcock.factoid: Woodcock are able to fly up to speeds of 50mph, making them one of the fastest birds in the air!

woodpecker.factoid: Woodpeckers can hammer at up to 12 times per second and up to 20,000 times a day!

worm.factoid: les?Wormholes are sometimes referred to as "Einstein-Rosen bridges," named after the two scientists who first proposed their existence.

wren.factoid: Wrens are some of the most vocal songbirds, often singing around dawn and dusk. They are known for their loud, complex songs that are made up of a combination of trills, chirps, and buzzes.

yak.factoid: aYakima is home to the Yakima Valley, which is known for being the nation's top hop-growing region and producing some of the best hops in the world.

zebra.factoid: Zebras have unique stripes that act as camouflage, and no two zebras have the same stripe pattern.

labrador.factoid: Labradors are the most popular breed in the United States and the United Kingdom.

german shepherd.factoid: German Shepherds are versatile and are commonly used as working dogs.

golden retriever.factoid: Golden Retrievers are known for their intelligence and loyalty.

bulldog.factoid: Bulldogs are gentle and loyal companions.

beagle.factoid: Beagles are friendly, curious, and active dogs.

lionhead rabbit.factoid: Lionheads sport a unique mane around their head and neck!

holland lop.factoid: Hollands are the smallest breed of lop-eared rabbits!

mini rex.factoid: Mini Rexes have a unique, velvety coat!

english angora.factoid: Angoras are known for their thick, luxurious fur!

dutch rabbit.factoid: Dutch rabbits are known for their distinct coloring!

maine coon.factoid: Maine Coons are the largest breed of domesticated cats and are known for their intelligence and playful personalities.

persian.factoid: Persians have a luxurious, long coat that requires daily grooming to keep it looking its best.

siamese.factoid: Siamese cats are known for their distinct blue eyes and their vocal personalities.

british shorthair.factoid: British Shorthairs are known for their gentle and relaxed temperaments.

ragdoll.factoid: Ragdoll cats are known for their affectionate, laid-back personalities and their tendency to go limp when held.
